<![CDATA[We are a community committed to following Jesus who deeply experience the love and presence of God by his Spirit. The Resurrection of Jesus: God's Receipt, Our Power - Bruce Latshaw
The Resurrection of Jesus: God's Receipt, Our Power - Bruce Latshaw

<![CDATA[We celebrate Good Friday because on the Cross Jesus bore our sins in His own body. He suffered the punishment and death due to all human beings. His passion satisfied our immeasurable debt to the Father that we could never have paid. Jesus paid it all and set us forever free. So what was the resurrection? Pastor Bruce Latshaw will give us insight into what the resurrection of Jesus was in the eyes of God and the watching universe, and what that pivotal point in divine history did for us, His ...]]>

We celebrate Good Friday because on the Cross Jesus bore our sins in His own body. He suffered the punishment and death due to all human beings. His passion satisfied our immeasurable debt to the Father that we could never have paid. Jesus paid it all and set us forever free. So what was the resurrection? Pastor Bruce Latshaw will give us insight into what the resurrection of Jesus was in the eyes of God and the watching universe, and what that pivotal point in divine history did for us, His kingdom people, forever.Â 

]]>

We celebrate Good Friday because on the Cross Jesus bore our sins in His own body. He suffered the punishment and death due to all human beings. His passion satisfied our immeasurable debt to the Father that we could never have paid. Jesus paid it all and set us forever free. So what was the resurrection? Pastor Bruce Latshaw will give us insight into what the resurrection of Jesus was in the eyes of God and the watching universe, and what that pivotal point in divine history did for us, His kingdom people, forever.Â

In this teaching we will look at the âfieryâ trial of three young Jewish men in the book of Daniel. We will find that God was in the business then and is in the business now of releasing His power in the midst of human challenges, making a way where there is no way.

<![CDATA[In this teaching Bruce unpacks the "giving" and "receiving" parts of Jesus' words, 'It is more blessed to give than to receive." He discusses what he calls the "law of flow"--that everything created, if alive, gives out and receives back as a primary dynamic of life. He counsels us to align ourselves with God's law by understanding and partaking in the giving and receiving of God's life in three areas: use of God's gifts in ministry, use of Scripture in prayer, and use of our resources. He notes that without participating in this "flow" through both giving and receiving, no Christian will be satisfied with any church, no matter how excellent the church, because receiving God's life flows from giving it away. He also touches on a challenge many of us have: wanting to be givers but not receivers, and how that problem can block the flow of God's life and resources into and through us. ]]>

Examining texts on the kingdom of God, we see that while the kingdom (the manifest reign and rule of God) has come and is "here" in the presence of the power of the Spirit of Christ, the fullness of God's kingdom is not yet here. Therefore, while Jesus has won the war, sometimes spiritual battles are lost to the enemy, as specific events in the New Testament show. This is "biblical reality" that helps explain why some are healed by God and some are not, even as Paul tells us that our "seeing" in prophecy is partial now, but will be complete when the "perfect" (the coming of Jesus and His kingdom) comes. Yet, Romans 8:28 remains true for the believer, as God miraculously works even enemy victories for "good" by His creative, redemptive grace. ]]>

<![CDATA[ In this "wild card" teaching, Bruce focuses on 2 Co. 5:17-"Anyone who is in Christ is a new creation. Old things have passed away, brand new things have come!" as the lynchpin of the transformation from our old "natural" self, shaped by this world, into our new "spiritual" self, created in the image of Jesus. All of the "new creation" began at the resurrection of Christ, including our "new person." Our old "man" separated from God, hostile to humanity and devoted to pleasing self, was dealt a death blow by the power of the Cross, so that we may live no longer as enemies of God. Instead our new identity includes acceptance replacing rejection, security vs. fear, inclusion vs. exclusion, favor vs. wrath, blessing vs. a curse. As we know and declare the reality of this new identity in Christ in us, we grow from glory to glory into its complete fulfillment. ]]>
